resources.string:
Type 2 diabetes

Type 2 diabetes is a chronic condition that occurs
when the pancreas does not produce enough insu
lin or the insulin does not work effectively to meet the body needs.

Type 2 diabetes:
• Represents 85 to 90 % of all cases of diabetes.
• Is more likely in people with a family history of ty
pe 2 diabetes or from particular ethnic backgroun
ds.
• Usually develops in adults over the age of 45 yea
rs but is increasingly occurring in younger age gro
ups.
• Can be delayed or prevented in 58 of cases.

Symptoms of Type 2 diabetes

Symptoms may include blurred vision, skin infect
ions, slow healing, tingling and numbness in the f
eet. Sometimes no symptoms are noticed at all.

Manage Diabetes Now



Congratulations – you’ve taken the first step in lea
rning more about managing your diabetes and livi
ng your life.

Diabetes Advisor is here to help you on your journ
ey. Learning about healthy food choices, the impor
tance of physical activity, the health care team, blo
od glucose monitoring and preventing complicatio
ns can help you to live well with type 2 diabetes.

Congratulations – you’ve taken the first step in learning more about managing your diabetes and living your life.Diabetes Advisor is here to help you on your journey. Learning about healthy food choices, the importance of physical activity, the health care team, blood glucose monitoring and preventing complications can help you to live well with type 2 diabetes.

Healthy eating is an important part of managing type 2 diabetes. This means paying close attenti
on to what, when, and how much you eat on a da
ily basis.

Physical activity Page:

Physical activity is vital in maintaining a healthy lif
estyle. By becoming more active you can improve
your general health, quality of life and diabetes man
agement.

Participating in regular physical activity helps to:
• Improve insulin sensitivity (makes insulin work bet
ter and lowers blood glucose levels)
• Improve blood pressure and lowers blood fats, whi
ch reduces the risk of heart disease
• Achieve and maintain a healthy body weight.
• Increase bone strength and reduce the risk of ost
eoporosis
• Improve quality of life and sense of well being.
• Slow down the ageing process

For the person with diabetes, physical
activity helps to
• Improve the body’s response to insulin which can
lower blood glucose level
• Lower blood pressure & cholesterol levels
• Reduce the risk of developing diabetes complica
tions

Activities:

• Aerobic activities that get your muscles moving
such as walking, swimming or cycling are recomm
ended.
• Strength training activities that make you use your
muscles such as squats, lifting weight are use yo recommended.
• For daily activity plan contact us on (provide email
id).

• My name is Kate and I’m just an ordinary person
leading an ordinary life. What makes me somewhat
different, is that I am living my ordinary life with Ty
pe 2 diabetes.

• I’d like to say that makes me unique, but the sad
truth is that every day, more and more people are
being diagnosed with this disease.Even worse,the
re are thousands uponn thousands of people who
don’t even know they are already affected.

• OK, so I have diabetes. Now what? When I saw the
doctor, she said I needed to exercise and change
my diet. Losing some weight would be benificial.Sh
e told me to get a glucose meter to check my blood
glucose at various times during the day: first thing
in the morning, before a meal, two hours after a me
al, at bedtime,when the moon is full, on trashday…
What? What did she say?

• Be mindful of what you’re eating and how much of
each thing: no more than so many grams of fat, so
much protein and about 30 grams of carbs per meal.

• I left that doctor’s office in a daze. I knew that I h
ad to make some changes, but I wasn’t sure where
to begin. I’m intelligent. I can figure this out! I just
had to deal with it.This App helped me a lot learning
about the life style that diabetes type 2 people have
to maintain. To overcome it.

Lowering blood pressure

• Losing weight and reducing waist measurement
• Balancing the omega fats in your diet
• Normalizing your weight
• Managing your emotional life
• Drugging yourself with exercise
• Appropriate sunshine exposure
• Experimenting with supplements and other alternative tips for improving your blood pressure
• Reduce sodium in your diet
• Limit the amount of alcohol you drink
• Breathe deeply
• Switch to decaf coffee

Lowering Cholesterol

• Being more active
• Taking medication
• Eat oily fish (for example, mackerel and salmon)
• Eat nuts (for example, almonds and cashews)
• Eat seeds (for example, sunflower and pumpkin)
• Eat vegetable oils and spreads (for example, sunflower, olive, corn, walnut and rapeseed oils).
• Avoid food containing saturated fats like : meat pies ,sausages and fatty cuts of meat, butter ,hard cheese, cakes and biscuits.

Lowering glucose levels

Blood glucose (day to day)
• Taking medication tablets or insulin
• Physical activity / exercise
• Limit foods high in added sugar
• Eating smaller portions of starchy carbohydrate
• Include a low GI food at every meal

Insulin resistance (long term)

• Eating less fat and saturated fat
• Losing weight and reducing waist circumference
• Being more active

Lowering blood pressure

• Losing weight and reducing waist measurement
• Balancing the omega fats in your diet
• Normalizing your weight
• Managing your emotional life
• Drugging yourself with exercise
• Appropriate sunshine exposure
• Experimenting with supplements and other alternative tips for improving your blood pressure
• Reduce sodium in your diet
• Limit the amount of alcohol you drink
• Breathe deeply
• Switch to decaf coffee

Start you STOP smoking with START :

S = Set a quit date.
T = Tell family, friends, and co-workers that you plan to quit.
A = Anticipate and plan for the challenges you wll face while quitting.
R = Remove cigarettes and other tobacco products from your home, car, and work.
T = Talk to your doctor about getting help to quit.

• Eating less fat (all type)
• Having less alcohol
• Eating smaller portions
• Being more physically active

• Benefits to being more active
 It helps you to relieve stress and anxiety and improves your mood
 It helps to lower your blood pressure
 It can improve the levels of cholesterol in your blood
 It can burn up kilojoules and help you lose weight
 It helps keep your heart healthy
• Recommended that you
 Accumulate 150 to 300 minutes of moderate intensity physical acitivity or 75 to 150 minutes of vigorous intensity physical activity or an equivalent combination of both activities, each week.
 Do muscle strengthening activities on at least two days each week.

• Eating less fat
• Changing from saturated to unsaturated fats
• Aim for a minimum of 2 serves of fruit and 5 serves vegetable daily
• Having less salt
• Alcohol within healthy limits (no more than 2 standard drinks each day)
• Smaller portion sizes leads to weight loss
• Fruits and vegetables

There are two ways to deal with depression:

• Pscyhotherapy or counseling by specialist in mental and emotional disorders.
• Antidepressent is useful but must be prescribed by primary care provider according to your blood sugar level.

• Contact your GP for intake of Aspirin
• An evaluation of risks versus benefits should be performed for each patients.
• The use of low dose aspirin is not recommended for those who have a low risk of cardiovascular disease with no additional major risk factors.
• A dose range of 75-162mg of aspirin daily is recommended.
